Answer: The difference in size is due to the way Java and C++ handle strings.

Java: Java strings are objects, and they contain a reference to the actual character array (the characters of the string) and some metadata about the string (like length and hashcode). This means that even if the characters of the string are very small, the string object itself can be quite large.

C++: C++ strings are just character arrays with a few extra bytes for metadata. This means that a string object in C++ is much closer to the size of the characters in the string than a Java string would be.

To measure the memory in Java, you can use the Instrumentation API. Here's an example:

```java
import java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation;

public class MemoryInstrumentation {
    private static Instrumentation instrumentation;

    public static void premain(String args, Instrumentation inst) {
        instrumentation = inst;
    }

    public static long getObjectSize(Object o) {
        return instrumentation.getObjectSize(o);
    }
}
```

You can then use `MemoryInstrumentation.getObjectSize(yourString)` to get the size of a string in bytes.

For C++, you can use the `sizeof` function to get the size of an object in bytes. For example, `sizeof(yourString)` will give you the size of the string object in bytes.

In both cases, you should note that the actual memory usage of an object can be larger than the size reported by these methods, because these methods only report the size of the object's metadata, not the size of the object's data.

Also, the actual memory usage can vary depending on the specifics of your JVM or C++ compiler, so it's always a good idea to test your code under realistic conditions to get a precise measurement.
